A nano-structured RuO2/NiO cathode enables the operation of non-aqueous lithium-air batteries in ambient air†
P. Tan, Z. H. Wei, W. Shyy, T. S. Zhao*, and X. B. Zhu
We report a cathode composed of RuO2 nanoparticle-decorated NiO nanosheets for a non-aqueous lithium-air battery. Unlike most of previous reported non-aqueous lithium-air batteries that are operated with pure oxygen only, we demonstrate that the present cathode enables the battery to be truly operated in ambient air at 500 mAh g-1 for 200 cycles (800 h), with stable coulombic efficiency (100%) and high energy efficiency (~75%). The stellar performance is attributed to the favorable combination of RuO2 nanoparticles and NiO nanosheets, which not only catalyzes the oxygen reduction and evolution reactions, but also promotes the decomposition of the side products, including lithium hydroxide and carbonates formed from to water and carbon dioxide in the air during discharge.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Non-aqueous lithium-air batteries have been considered as one of the most promising power sources for electric vehicles and portable devices,1 primarily due to the super-high energy density as a result of two factors. First, lithium is the lightest metal and has the highest specific capacity of 3.86×103 mAh g-1, corresponding to a specific energy density of 1.14×104 Wh kg-1 for a theoretical potential of 2.96 V.2 Second, the cathode active material, oxygen, can be obtained from ambient air without occupying the battery volume. Hence, based on the consideration of the entire battery system, the energy density of non-aqueous lithium-air batteries is several times higher than that of Li-ion batteries.3-6
The main electrochemical reactions in non-aqueous lithium-air batteries during discharge and charge are the reversible formation and decomposition of lithium peroxide (Li2O2) as
2Li+ + 2e- + O2 ⇄ Li2O2 (E 0=2.96 V vs. Li/Li+) (1)
As oxygen is a reactant, obtaining oxygen from atmospheric air is a key issue for the battery operation. However, most previously reported lithium-air batteries were operated in a pure oxygen environment with an oxygen pressure equal to or greater than 1.0 atm,7 while the common ambient air is composed of oxygen with a partial pressure of only 0.21 atm and other gases (e.g. N2, CO2, H2O). The barriers for the operation in ambient air are the contamination of lithium anode by water and carbon dioxide8,9 and the side reactions in the cathode during discharge as follows:10
4Li+ + 4e- + O2 + 2CO2 → 2Li2CO3 (E 0=3.82 V vs. Li/Li+) (2) 4Li+ + 4e- + O2 + 2H2O → 4LiOH (E 0=3.39 V vs. Li/Li+) (3)
2LiOH + CO2 → Li2CO3 + H2O (4)
2Li2O2 + 2H2O → 4LiOH + O2 (5)
Even though a lithium-protected anode is applied to avoid the contamination of lithium metal,11 the poor chargeability of LiOH and Li2CO3 has been theoretically 12 and experimentally10 demonstrated. Hence, one solution to enable the operation nonaqueous lithium-air batteries in ambient air is to use an oxygen selective membrane that only allows oxygen to enter the battery.1317 However, the substantial thickness and limited surface area of reported membranes cause an increase in the oxygen transport resistance, leading to a sacrifice in the battery’s performance.18 Recently, Zhu et al.19 reported a solid-state lithium-air battery with a thin silicone-oil film coated on the cathode pores. This integrated film can not only block water vapor and carbon dioxide from reaching reaction sites, but allow a high rate of oxygen transport, enabling the battery to operate in ambient air with a high rate and long cycle life. Unfortunately, such design is hard to be applied in non-aqueous lithium-air batteries due to the liquid electrolyte. Hence, developing an oxygen selective membrane that with high oxygen permeability and selectively is still challenging.
As electrocatalysts have been widely used to lower the
overpotential in the Li2O2 decomposition, 20 a new strategy to enable the operation in ambient air is to find a proper catalyst that can efficiently promote the decomposition of side products (Li2CO3, LiOH). Li et al.21 found that NiO can act as a catalyst to decompose Li2CO3. They also developed a Li/CO2:O2 (2:1) battery and a Li/CO2 battery in which Li2CO3 is the main product that can discharge and charge reversibly.22 Lim et al.23 found that the electrochemical activation of CO2 within the high dielectric medium of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) can enable the reversible formation of Li2CO3. Zhou et al. reported a rechargeable Li-CO2 battery based on a graphene cathode24 and a carbon nanotubes (CNTs) cathode.25 Hong et al.26 demonstrated that the active oxidation of carbonate/carboxylate species can be realized through using NiO plates as the catalyst. Tong et al.27 reported that NiO nanosheet exhibites a good activity for the decomposition of Li2O2 and Li2CO3, enabling the battery to cycle 40 times at a fixed capacity of 500 mAh g-1. Zhou et al.28 showed that the decomposition of LiOH is

Based on the above results, in this work, we fabricate a cathode composed of RuO2 nanoparticle-decorated NiO nanosheets, which can enable a non-aqueous lithium-air to be operated in ambient air due to the favorable combination: RuO2 can catalyze the oxygen reduction and evolution reactions,29-36 and also promote the decomposition of lithium hydroxide;28,37 NiO nanosheets can promote the decomposition of carbonates and carboxylates,26 and meanwhile provide a large surface area for the utilization of RuO2 nanoparticles. We first tested the stability of this electrode towards the electrolyte. Then, the electrochemical performance of this electrode under pure oxygen was characterized. Moreover, a non-aqueous lithium-air battery with this cathode was operated in ambient air, and the cycling stability was further investigated.

sections.heading: Experimental
sections.text:
Fabrication of RuO2 nanoparticle-decorated NiO nanosheet electrode
The RuO2 nanoparticle-decorated NiO nanosheet electrode was fabricated through two steps, as illustrated in Scheme 1. Firstly, the NiO nanosheet-anchored nickel foam was fabricated as previously reported:38 The commercial nickel foam was degreased by sonicating in acetone for 5 min, rinsed with deionized water and dried in air. Subsequently, the nickel foam was immersed in a 0.5 M oxalic acid ethanol solution with 5 wt% water. The reaction was kept at a constant temperature of 45 oC for 1.0 h. Afterwards, the nickel foam was rinsed in deionized water, anhydrous ethanol and dried in air, followed by thermal decomposition in a resistance furnace at 400 oC for 45 min in air. Then, the NiO nanosheetanchored nickel foam was obtained and donated as NiO/Ni. The loading of NiO nanosheets on the nickel foam is obtained by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, Fig. S1).
Scheme 1 Schematic illustrations showing the two-step fabrication process of the RuO2 nanoparticle-decorated NiO nanosheets electrode.
To decorate RuO2 nanoparticles onto the surfaces of NiO nanosheets, a 10 mM RuCl3•xH2O solution was first prepared in acidic solution at pH 2.3. The dilute NaOH solution was dropped into the RuCl3•xH2O solution until the pH was approximately 10.0; a Ru(OH)3 solution was then obtained in the form of suspended particles.39 After the precursor solution was stirred for 1 h, it was rinsed 5 times with anhydrous ethanol. The Ru(OH)3 particles were then redispersed in ethanol. The Ru(OH)3 precursor was dropped directly onto the prepared NiO nanosheet-anchored nickel foam. After drying for 30 min, the sample was placed at the center of the furnace at 300 °C for 4 h in air and cooled to room temperature.
Finally, RuO2 nanoparticles decorated NiO nanosheets were fabricated, and donated as RuO2/NiO. The loading of RuO2 was obtained by TGA (Fig. S1). To investigate the function of NiO nanosheets, a RuO2 decorated Ni electrode (RuO2/Ni) with the same RuO2 loading was also fabricated. The Ni, NiO/Ni, RuO2/Ni, and RuO2/NiO electrodes for electrochemical tests were all cut into discs with a diameter of 14 mm.

sections.heading: Material characterization
sections.text: The morphologies of Ni, NiO/Ni, and RuO2/NiO electrodes were observed by a scanning electron microscope (SEM, JEOL-6700F) under an acceleration voltage of 5.0 kV. The elemental distribution was studied on a SEM (JEOL-6300 and 6700) with energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDS) operating at 15 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained by operating a highresolution JEOL 2010F TEM system with a LaB6 filament at 200 kV. The samples were dispersed in ethanol, sonicated and dripped onto the holey carbon-coated Cu grids. The BET surface areas of the electrodes were examined via nitrogen adsorption-desorption. The compositions of the Ni, NiO/Ni, and RuO2/NiO electrodes were analyzed by a Philips high-resolution X-ray diffraction system (XRD, model PW 1825) using a Cu-Kα source operating at 40 keV and a Micro-Raman spectrophotometer (Renishaw RM 3000) at 514 nm exciting wavelength. A Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) test was carried out on a spectrometer (Vertex 70, Bruker) in the frequency range of 400-1800 cm-1. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterization was determined by a Physical Electronics PHI 5600 multi-technique system using Al monochromatic X-ray at a power of 350 W. The peak position correction was corrected by referencing the C 1s peak position of carbon.

sections.heading: Electrochemical characterization
sections.text:
To test the stabilities of Ni, NiO/Ni, and RuO2/NiO electrodes toward the electrolyte, two kinds of widely-used electrolytes were prepared: the one is 1 M lithium Bis(Trifluoromethanesulfonyl)Imide (LiTFSI, Sigma-Aldrich, 99.95%) in tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether (TEGDME, Sigma-Aldrich, 99%), and the other is 1 M lithium perchlorate (LiClO4, 99.99%, Sigma-Aldrich) in anhydrous dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, ≥99.9%, Sigma-Aldrich). After preparation, both electrolytes were dried with molecular sieves and the water concentration was less than 5 ppm. The anodic linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) test was comprised of the working electrode (WE) of Ni, NiO/Ni, or RuO2/NiO electrode, the counter electrode (CE) and reference electrode (RE) of Li metals and bulk electrolyte with oxygen saturation. The tests were conducted using a potentiostat/galvanostat (PARSTAT 2273) from open circuit potential (OCP) to 5.0 V at a sweep rate of 1 mV s-1. To test the electrocatalytic activities for side products, the RuO2/NiO electrode was first galvanostatly discharged using carbonate electrolytes (EC: DMC=1:3, H2O≤4 ppm) at the current density of 0.0125 mA cm-2. After that, the discharged electrode was washed with pure TEGDME and dried under vacuum. Another two electrodes were prepared by pre-filling with commercial LiOH (Fluka, ≥99.9%), and Li2CO3 (Sigma-Aldrich, ≥99.0%) particles with the particle size of 1~5µm. The following anodic LSV was performed

in 1.0 M LiTFSI/TEGDME electrolyte from OCP to 4.0 V at a sweep rate of 1 mV s-1.
The electrochemical performance of the prepared electrodes in oxygen was tested in a home-made lithium-oxygen battery contains a lithium metal foil anode, a glass-fiber separator (Whatman GF/C), and the cathode electrode as prepared, with the electrolyte of 1.0 M LiTFSI/TEGDME. The battery was assembled in an argon-filled glove box (Etelux, Lab 2000) at water and oxygen contents below 1 ppm. After assembly, the inlet of the battery was tightly connected to high purity oxygen (≥99.997%, H2O≤1 ppm, CO2≤1 ppm) with a constant flow to exhaust the remaining argon. Then, the outlet of the battery was sealed and the battery was exposed to oxygen at a constant pressure of about 1 atm. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) experiments were carried out in a potentiostat/galvanostat (PARSTAT 2273) at a scan rate of 0.25 mV s-1 in the potential range of 2.0-4.2 V (vs. Li/Li+) to investigate the kinetics of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) occurred in the electrode. The galvanostatic discharge and charge tests were conducted on a battery cycling system (Neware, CT-3008W) at a current density of 250 mA g-1 based on the loading of RuO2. To test the energy efficiencies of the RuO2/NiO electrode, the battery was discharged and charged continuously at the current density of 250, 500, and 100 mA g-1 at a fixed capacity of 1000 mAh g-1. The cycling stability tests were performed at the current densities of 250 and 500 mA g-1 with a fixed capacity of 500 mAh g-1, respectively.
The performance of the RuO2/NiO electrode in ambient air was first tested in a home-made battery with a lithium metal foil anode and 1.0 M LiTFSI/TEGDME electrolyte. After assembling in an argonfilled glove box, the battery was put out in ambient air with RH of 60±5%. The stability test was conducted in a battery with a LiFePO4 anode electrode, which was made of LiFePO4, carbon powder, and PTFE with the weight ratio of 7:2:1. Before use, the electrode is dried at 120 oC under vacuum for 12 hours and activated. The cycling stability was examined at 250 mA g-1 with a fixed capacity of 500 mAh g-1. All tests were performed at the temperature of 23±2 oC.
The cathode compositions after discharge and charge were analyzed by FTIR and XPS. The cathode morphologies after discharge and charge were observed by a SEM. To obtain the cathode after test, the battery was disassembled in the argon glove box, and the cathode was rinsed by pure TEGDME to remove the residual lithium salt over the cathode surface, and then dried at room temperature in a vacuum chamber. For all measurements, a home-made gas container filled with argon was used to transfer the cathodes.

sections.heading: Characterization of the RuO2/NiO electrode
sections.text:
The XRD patterns of the Ni, NiO/Ni, and RuO2/NiO electrodes in the range of 2θ from 30o to 90o are shown in Fig. 1a. For all electrodes, three strong peaks are corresponding to nickel. For the NiO/Ni electrode, three additional diffraction peaks were identified to be the (111), (200), and (220) peaks of NiO (JCPDS # 47-1049). For the RuO2/NiO electrode, in addition to the peaks corresponding to nickel and nickel oxide, three weak peaks were identified to be the
(101), (200), and (211) peaks of RuO2 (JCPDS # 40-1290), suggesting that RuO2 was formed. To further confirm the formation of NiO and RuO2, the Raman spectra of three cathodes were tested, as shown in Fig. 1b. For the NiO/Ni cathode, peaks due to one-phonon (1P), two-phonon (2P) and two-magnon (2M) scattering of NiO were all detected.40 For the RuO2/NiO cathode, three new peaks located at 514, 629, and 685 cm-1 correspond to the Eg, A1g, and B2g Raman active modes of RuO2, respectively (Fig. S2). 30
Fig. 1 Characterization of the Ni, NiO/Ni, and RuO2/NiO electrodes: (a) XRD patterns and (b) Raman spectra.
Fig. 2 SEM and TEM images of the Ni, NiO/Ni, and RuO2/NiO electrodes: (a) The surface morphology of (a) Ni foam and (b) NiO nanosheet-anchored nickel foam; (c) high-resolution SEM image of NiO nanosheets; (d) high-resolution SEM image of the RuO2 nanoparticle-decorated NiO nanosheets; (e) TEM image of a RuO2 nanoparticle-decorated NiO nanosheet (inset: the histograms of RuO2 particle size distribution); and (f) High-resolution TEM image of a RuO2 nanoparticle on the surface of a NiO nanosheet, with lattice fringes of RuO2 and NiO, respectively.
The SEM images of the prepared electrodes are shown in Fig. 2a-d. The Ni electrode has a smooth surface, as shown in Fig. 2a. After the fabrication of nickel oxide, the surface shows a nanosheet-like morphology (Fig. 2b). From the enlarged view in Fig. 2c, NiO

nanosheets have an ultrathin structure with a thickness of less than 10 nm, and interconnect with each other to form clusters. Such tangled morphologies may enhance the structure stability.38 Moreover, each nanosheet is composed of nanoparticles with the diameter of 5.14 nm (Fig. S3), leading to an increased specific area and a mesoporous structure (Fig. S4). After the introduction of RuO2 nanoparticles, as shown in Fig. 2d, the RuO2/NiO electrode maintains its tangled morphology. From the EDS mapping results (Fig. S5) and TEM image in Fig. 2e, RuO2 nanoparticles are decorated on the surfaces of NiO nanosheets, with an average particle size of 10.64 nm. The specific surface area of the RuO2/NiO electrode decreases, which may be caused by the dense RuO2. But its pore distribution is similar to that of the NiO/Ni electrode, indicating that the mesoporous structure of NiO nanosheets remains the same (Fig. S4). The high-resolution TEM image in Fig. 2f shows a RuO2 nanoparticle on the NiO surface, and the regular interplanar spacing of 2.25 Å is ascribed to the (200) plane of RuO2 (JCPDS # 40-1290), indicating the crystalline nature of the particles. The results demonstrate that RuO2 nanoparticles are successfully synthesized and decorated on the surface of NiO nanosheets.
Electrocatalytic activity for side products
Previous study indicates that the onset potential for blank NiO/CNT in 0.5 M LiTFSI/TEGDME is about 4.85 V, showing a high stability towards electrolyte during the battery operation (below 4.5 V).26 However, with the addition of RuO2 nanoparticles and non-carbon substrate, the stabilities toward the electrolyte are unknown. Hence, we test the stabilities of Ni, NiO/Ni, and RuO2/NiO
Fig. 3 Anodic LSV curves of blank Ni, NiO/Ni, and RuO2/NiO electrodes in (a) 1.0 M LiTFSI/TEGDME and (b) 1.0 M LiClO4/DMSO at a sweep rate of 1 mV s−1. (1) shows the LSV in the range from open circuit potential (~3.0 V) to 5.0 V; (2) shows zoomed-in each profile of blank Ni (black, bottom), blank NiO/Ni (red, middle), and blank RuO2/NiO (blue, top) from (1) around the onset potential.
electrodes in two kinds of widely-used electrolytes (1.0 M LiTFSI/TEGDME and 1.0 M LiClO4/DMSO), and the results are shown in Fig. 3. Fig. 3a shows the LSV curves in 1.0 M LiTFSI/TEGDME. For the Ni electrode, the onset potential is about 4.82 V, indicating that nickel foam is a stable substrate/current collector in TEGDME. For the NiO/Ni electrode, however, the onset potential decreases to 4.54 V. Different from the situation in which CNT was used as the support,26 this result shows that NiO can introduce the d ecomposition of TEGDME to some extent. With the decoration of RuO2 nanoparticles, the onset potential further decreases to 4.42 V. Considering that RuO2 can result in a low charge voltage (~4.0 V),29,30,32,34,35,41 it is still applicable to use RuO2/NiO electrode in TEGDME electrolyte. Fig. 3b shows the LSV curves in 1.0 M LiClO4/DMSO. Different from the results in 1.0 M LiTFSI/TEGDME, the onset potential for Ni electrode is only about 3.26 V. With an increase in the potential, the side products may cover the nickel surface, alleviating further decomposition. As a result, the current decreases after 4.0 V. When the nickel surfaces are cover with NiO nanosheets, the onset potential increases to 3.42 V. For the RuO2/NiO electrode, although the onset potential is still as low as 3.55 V, it is interesting to find that it leads to a current one order of magnitude lower than those of the Ni and NiO/Ni electrodes. Hence, nickel seems not to be suitable substrate/current collector in DMSO electrolyte; but the stability can increase with the surface coverage.42 Based on the above results, in our following study, we focused on the tests in 1.0 M LiTFSI/TEGDME electrolyte.
To investigate the electrocatalytic activities for the
decomposition of side products (e.g. LiOH, Li2CO3), the RuO2/NiO electrode was first discharged in carbonate electrolytes, followed by anodic LSV in 1.0 M LiTFSI/TEGDME electrolyte. As shown in Fig. 4 inset, although the discharge voltage is quite high in carbonate electrolytes, as the electrolyte have poor O2 - tolerance,43,44 the products like Li2CO3 and HCO2Li are formed as the predominant products (Figs. S6 and S7) instead of Li2O2. 45,46 These side products are formed in a stable electrolyte (e.g. TEGDME) by the reaction between electrolyte and Li2O2. 47 Hence, the subsequent anodic LSV shows the act ive oxidation potential, with respect to the

decomposition of side products.26 In comparison, another two electrodes with pre-filled LiOH and Li2CO3 were also tested, and the results are shown in Fig. 4. The onset potential of the pre-filled LiOH electrode is 3.31 V, which is consistent with the reported value of Ru in the oxidation of LiOH (~3.27 V),28 indicating the electrocatalytic activity of the RuO2/NiO electrode in the LiOH decomposition (Fig. S8). For the electrode pre-filled with Li2CO3, the onset potential is 3.56 V, which is lower than that of the NiO plate.21 A LSV test of the NiO/Ni electrode pre-filled with Li2CO3 shows the activity of NiO nanosheets in the decomposition of Li2CO3 (Fig. S8). For the electrode with discharged side products, the onset potential is 3.65 V, a little higher than that of Li2CO3 due to the involvement of lithium carboxylates (e.g. HCO2Li). Due to the large particle size of LiOH and Li2CO3 (1~3 µm) and poor contact with the electrode, the current densities are lower than that with side products. As the RuO2/NiO electrode is stable towards TEGDME electrolyte under 4.0 V, the results demonstrate the electrocatalytic activities of RuO2/NiO for the oxidation of side products.
Electrochemical performance in pure oxygen
The electrocatalytic activities for ORR and OER of the Ni, NiO/Ni, and RuO2/NiO electrodes were investigated using CV in the potential range of 2.0 ~ 4.2 V (vs. Li/Li+), and the results are shown in Fig. 5a. For the Ni electrode, almost no ORR or OER activities are presented. With the addition of NiO nanosheets, both the anodic and cathodic currents increases, but the improvement is limited. Compared with the NiO/Ni electrode, the RuO2/NiO electrode exhibits an order of magnitude higher ORR current density, which may be related to the superior electrocatalytic of the RuO2 nanoparticles.29 During anodic scan, the decomposition voltage of the discharge product start at 3.60 V, with a large current density, indicating that the electrode also has good OER activity. Hence, the RuO2/NiO electrode has good electrocatalytic activities for ORR and OER, and the performance comes from RuO2 nanoparticles rather than NiO nanosheets.
Fig. 5 The electrochemical performance of Ni, NiO/Ni, and RuO2/NiO electrodes in 1.0 M LiTFSI/TEGDME electrolyte: (a) The CV curves of three different electrodes in the potential range of 2.0-
4.2 V (vs. Li/Li+); (b) The discharge-charge profiles of lithium-oxygen batteries based on three different cathodes at the same current density; (c) Discharge-charge profiles of a battery with the RuO2/NiO electrode at various current densities ranging from 250 to 1000 mA gRuO2 -1 at a fixed capacity of 1000 mAh gRuO2 -1; and (d) The corresponding energy efficiencies of the RuO2/NiO electrode at various current densities.
The discharge and charge curves of a lithium-oxygen battery
with the Ni, NiO/Ni, and RuO2/NiO cathode at the current density of 0.0125 mA cm-2 are present in Fig. 5b, respectively. For the Ni cathode, the discharge voltage quickly decreases to 2.3 V, with a capacity of only 0.9 µAh cm-2. For the NiO/Ni cathode, although NiO nanosheets have a large surface area, no discharge voltage plateau is presented, and a capacity of 0.011 mAh cm-2 is delivered. In comparison, the RuO2/NiO cathode shows a discharge voltage plateau of 2.75 V and a capacity of 0.162 mAh cm-2. A test in the argon atmosphere shows that this capacity comes from the oxygen reduction reaction,29 rather than the reduction of RuO2 (Fig. S9). Hence, the RuO2/NiO electrode has a good discharge performance in oxygen, which agrees well with the CV results. As NiO nanosheets only contribute to 6.7% of the total capacity, we treat the capacity of the RuO2/NiO cathode based on the loading of RuO2, which is about 3240 mAh g-1. In comparison, as shown in Fig. S10, the discharge performance of the battery with the RuO2/Ni cathode in pure oxygen shows a decrease in the discharge voltage of 2.60 V with a capacity of 0.083 mAh cm-2 (1675 mAh g-1). Hence, such a high capacity of the RuO2/NiO cathode may result from the improved utilization of RuO2 nanoparticles onto the increased surface area of NiO nanosheets (Fig. S11). On charge, a capacity of 2080 mAh g-1 can be charged below 4.0 V (64.2%), and the voltage reaches 4.17 V toward the end of charge.
The reversibility of Li2O2 formation and decomposition on the
RuO2/NiO cathode has been verified by FTIR and XPS spectra of the fully discharged and charged cathodes. As shown in Fig. 6a, the absorbance peak at around 540 cm-1 is derived from Li2O2 in the discharged RuO2/NiO cathode. In addition, an absorbance peak at around 860 cm-1 is from Li2CO3, which may be formed by the decomposition of electrolyte in contact with Li2O2. 47,48 After charge, the both peaks disappeared, suggesting the decomposition of Li2O2 and Li2CO3. Fig. 6b compares the Li 1s XPS spectra of the discharged and charged cathodes. The Li 1s region for the RuO2/NiO cathode after discharge includes a contribution from the underlying Li2O2 (Li 1s: 54.6 eV) and surface lithium carbonate species (Li 1s: 55.3 eV)47 formed by the reaction between the electrolyte and Li2O2. Upon charging, both peaks disappear, suggesting the decomposition of Li2O2 and the carbonate species, 48 which is consistent with the FTIR results. Moreover, SEM characterization was used to further confirm to reversible Li2O2 formation and decomposition. For the fully discharged cathode, as shown in Fig. 6c, the surface was covered by toroid-shaped Li2O2 nanoparticles with size ranging from 200 to 400 nm. This kind of morphology is consistent with the previous report, in which the toroid-shaped Li2O2 particles were observed on the cathode made of two-dimensional RuO2 nanosheets.35 After charge, no Li2O2 particles can be found in the cathode by SEM (Fig. 6d), indicating the discharge products completely decomposed. On the basis of the above FTIR, XPS, and

SEM results, it is demonstrated that for the RuO2/NiO cathode, Li2O2, as the major discharge product, is reversibly formed in the discharge process and is decomposed in the subsequent charge process.
Fig. 6 Characterization of the RuO2/NiO cathode after discharge and charge: (a) FTIR spectra; (b) Li 1s spectra; SEM images of (c) fully discharged and (d) fully charged RuO2/NiO cathode.
The rate performance of the RuO2/NiO electrode was investigated at the current densities ranging from 250 to 1000 mA g-1 with a fixed capacity of 1000 mAh g-1, as shown in Fig. 5c. At a low current density of 250 mA g-1, the discharge voltage is about 2.73 V, which continuously decreases to 2.64 V at 500 mA g-1 and 2.58 V at 1000 mA g-1. The terminal charge voltage goes from 4.02 to 4.18 V with the current density increasing from 250 to 1000 mA g-1. Hence, the energy efficiency is calculated to be 74.6%, 72.3%, and 69.6% at the current density of 250, 500, and 1000 mA g-1, respectively, as shown in Fig. 5d. Additionally, when the current density is set back to 250 mA g-1, the discharge/charge voltages are almost identical to the initial ones, with a recovered energy
efficiency of 74.2%, demonstrating a good stability of the RuO2/NiO cathode.
As this RuO2/NiO cathode has the ability to decompose side products, a good cycling stability in a non-aqueous lithium-oxygen battery is expected. As shown in Fig. 7a1, at the current density of 250 mA g-1, the discharge voltage plateau for the first cycle is about 2.75 V, and the charge voltage reaches 3.93 V at the end of the charge process. Such a high discharge voltage and a low charge voltage results in an energy efficiency as high as 78.4%. With an increase in the cycle number, as shown in Fig. 7a2, the terminal discharge voltage decreases to 2.45 V after 50 cycles, and the charge voltage increases to 4.09 V, leading to a decreased energy efficiency of 70.6%. As TEGDME has a vapor pressure of ~10-5 bar at room temperature,49 the effect of evaporation can be neglected. When considering the stability during discharge and charge process, previous investigations showed that TEGDME starts to decompose at 4.3 V,50 and our LSV test indicates that the onset potential is 4.42 V. In our cycling test, the terminal charge voltages are around 4.0 V, lower than the voltage for TEGDME decomposition. Although the decomposition of electrolyte in contact with Li2O2 has been observed, it was found that the electrode and separator were still wetted with the electrolyte after dissembling the battery, as shown in Fig. S12a. Thus, the electrolyte consumption is not thought to be the direct cause of the increased overpotential during cycling. The lithium anode, on the other hand, was covered with a black layer at its interface with the separator (Fig. S12b) as reported elsewhere.51 Therefore, we inferred that the increased overpotential is mainly because of the lithium anode.52,53 To verify this assumption, we rebuilt the battery with this cycled cathode but a new lithium anode, a new separator, and fresh electrolyte.54 As shown in Fig. 7a3, the discharge and charge voltage profiles of the rebuilt battery are almost identical to the initial one, and the battery can be cycled with similar voltage profiles and energy efficiency (Fig. S13). Similar results can be seen at the current density of 500 mA g-1 in Fig. 7b. Thus, this RuO2/NiO cathode enables a non-aqueous lithium-oxygen battery to deliver stable voltages and energy efficiency, demonstrating excellent cycling stability.

sections.heading: Operating in ambient air
sections.text:
As the good performance of this RuO2/NiO cathode under pure oxygen is demonstrated, we further operate a non-aqueous lithiumair battery with this cathode in ambient air at the current density of 250 mAh g-1, and the results are shown in Fig. 8a and Fig. S14. As the oxygen pressure in ambient air is only 0.21 atm, at the initial discharge stage, the voltage plateau is only 2.65 V, which is about 100 mV lower than that in pure oxygen. With an increase in the capacity, it is interesting to find that the discharge voltage shows an increase, which may be attributed to the side reactions caused by H2O and CO2, as expressed in Eqs. 2 and 3. After reach the capacity of ~ 800 mAh g-1, the discharge voltage gradually decreases. Eventually, the battery delivers a capacity of 3465 mAh g-1, about 7% higher than that in pure oxygen (3240 mAh g-1), which may be attributed to the participation of H2O and CO2 in the discharge process.55-57 To verify this, we examined the discharge product composition, and the result is shown in Fig. 8b. After discharge, a peak corresponding to Li2O2 can be detected, which comes from the oxygen reduction reaction as expressed in Eq. 1. The strong oxidizing property of Li2O2 can cause a decomposition of the electrolyte, leading to the formation of some lithium carboxylate species. Besides, strong peaks corresponding to LiOH and Li2CO3 are clearly shown in FTIR results. Hence, different from the product in pure oxygen which is mainly Li2O2, more complicated products are formed when operating in ambient air.
shown in Fig. 8a. Similar to the charge performance in pure oxygen,
the voltage gradually increases. However, only a capacity of 1740 mAh g-1 can be recovered below the voltage of 4.0 V (50%), and the voltage reaches as high as 4.40 V toward the end of charge. When examining the cathode after charge, as shown in Fig. 8b, some product peaks disappear (e.g. LiOH and Li2CO3 at ~1430 cm -1), demonstrating the catalytic activities of the cathode for the side product decomposition. However, some product peaks still remain. The SEM image of the charged cathode in Fig. 8d also confirms that the cathode surfaces are covered by some film-like products. The reason may be attributed to the contamination of lithium metal anode, on which surface is fully covered by LiOH and Li2CO3, as shown in Fig. 8c (marked as the shaded areas). These products passivate the lithium anode, increasing the lithium ion transport resistance, leading to a high charge voltage (e.g. 4.40 V). Such a high voltage can cause the decomposition of the electrolyte, and eventually resulting in the failure of the capacity recovery. Although the passivation of the lithium anode due to oxygen crossover has been reported,52,53 the contamination of H2O and CO2 in ambient air is much severe. Hence, a protected lithium anode (one in which the lithium metal is isolated from the non-aqueous electrolyte by a lithium ion conducting but electronically insulating membrane) 58 should be used in non-aqueous lithium-air batteries when running with ambient air.8
To study the stability of this RuO2/NiO cathode in ambient air,
for present study we employed LiFePO4 anode in a battery instead of lithium metal to reduce the contamination,58-60 and the voltage was converted versus Li/Li+ (Fig. S15). The battery was tested under the current density of 250 mA g-1 with a fixed capacity of 500 mAh g-1, and the results are shown in Fig. 9. Fig. 9a shows the discharge-

For the first cycle, the terminal discharge voltage is 2.56 V, and the terminal charge voltage is about 4.16 V. The larger overpotentials in ambient air are attributed to the different gas atmosphere, which results in different product composition and morphology.61 After the first cycle, the discharge voltage gradually increases, and the charge voltage decreases, which may be caused by the increased oxygen concentration in the electrolyte and the participation of H2O and CO2 in the electrochemical reactions.62 After the 20th cycle, the gas species may become balanced in the electrolyte, leading to a stable discharge and charge voltages, as shown in Fig. 9b, and the terminal discharge and charge voltage is around 2.80 and 4.02 V, respectively. Even after 200 cycles, the initial capacity is retained, with the columbic efficiency of 100% and the energy efficiency of around 75%, as shown in Fig. 9c, indicating an excellent stability.
To look inside the cycling performance in ambient air, the
product compositions after discharge and charge were examined by FITR, and the morphology was observed by SEM, as shown in Figs. 10 and 11, respectively. After the 1st discharge, the cathode surface is covered by some particle-like products, as shown in Fig. 11a1, and FTIR results indicate that the products are composed of Li2O2, LiOH,

After the 20th discharge, the peaks corresponding to Li2O2 are hard to be detected; while the peaks corresponding to LiOH and Li2CO3 are clearly seen, and a weak peak of lithium carboxylate can also be detected, as shown in Fig. 10. This result indicates the participation of H2O and CO2 in the discharge process, which is consistent with the voltage changes in Fig. 9. The SEM in Fig. 11b1 also shows a nanosheet-like morphology, with some small particles, as previously reported morphologies of LiOH and Li2CO3. 19,23 After charge, the cathode surface becomes clean, and the product peaks disappear. With an increase in the cycling, the products are mainly composed of LiOH and Li2CO3, especially the latter one, which is consistent with the reported results by Zhou et al.58 Even after the 200th cycle,

To compare the present performance with reported results, we summarized the lithium-air batteries directly operated in ambient air without oxygen selective membrane, as listed in Table. 1. Most reported batteries are in the solid-state or quasisolid-state types, with the electrolytes made of gel polymer or glass ceramics (e.g. Li1+xAlxTi2-x(PO4)3 — LATP, Li1+xAlxGe2-x(PO4)3 — LAGP). For the liquid based lithium-air batteries, Shen et al.8 reported a nonaqueous lithium-air battery using Pd modified carbon nanotube cathode, and this battery can be operated in ambient air for 16 cycles (about 1 week). However, the accumulation of Li2CO3 caused
the charge voltage as high as 4.6 V, leading to the poor cyclability. Yi et al. 66 reported a battery with TEGDME electrolyte and super P cathode, which could only operate for 8 cycles (80 h) in ambient air due to severe side reactions. For the solid-state or quasisolid-state lithium-air batteries, although a long cycle life of 1880 h (100 cycles) has been reported,62 due to the accumulation of Li2CO3, the charge voltage reaches as high as 5.0 V and the charge capacity starts to decay since the 30th cycle (after 600 h). In this work, as the cathode has a subtle combination of RuO2 nanoparticles and NiO nanosheets, which not only catalyzes the oxygen reduction and evolution reactions, but also promotes the decomposition of the side products (Li2CO3 and LiOH), enabling a stable cycling for 200 times (800 h).

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
In this work, we fabricated a cathode composed of RuO2 nanoparticle-decorated NiO nanosheets for a non-aqueous lithium-air battery. In pure oxygen atmosphere, a battery with this cathode delivers a capacity of 3240 mAh g-1. The reversible formation and decomposition of Li2O2 as the main product in the discharge and charge processes are demonstrated by FTIR, XPS and SEM. It is shown that at a fixed capacity of 1000 mAh g-1, the energy efficiency of the battery reaches 74.6%, 72.3%, and 69.6% at a current density of 250, 500, and 1000 mA g-1, respectively. In addition, a good cycling stability of this
cathode is also presented at a fixed capacity of 500 mAh g-1. When operated in ambient air with the relative humidity of 60±5%, a battery with this cathode delivers a capacity of 3465 mAh g-1, higher than that in pure oxygen due to the participation of H2O and CO2 in the discharge process. FTIR result showed that the main discharge products are the combination of Li2O2, LiOH, and Li2CO3. A battery fitted with the present cathode can be operated in ambient air at 500 mAh g-1 for 200 cycles (800 h), with stable coulombic efficiency (100%) and high energy efficiency (~75%). FITR and SEM results further show that LiOH and Li2CO3 can be reversibly formed and decomposed during cycling. The stellar performance is attributed to the favorable combination of

Graphic abstract
A cathode composed of RuO2 nanoparticle-decorated NiO nanosheets not only
catalyzes the oxygen reduction and evolution reactions, but also promotes the
decomposition of the side products (lithium hydroxide and lithium carbonate),
enabling a non-aqueous lithium-air battery to be truly operated in ambient air at 500
mAh g -1 for 200 cycles (800 h), with stable coulombic efficiency (100%) and high
energy efficiency (~75%).

Broader context
Non-aqueous lithium-air batteries are expected to have a super-high energy density,
due to the usage of the lightest metal lithium and oxygen from ambient air without
occupying the battery volume. The reversible formation and decomposition of the
product, lithium peroxide, render the battery rechargeable. However, non-aqueous
lithium-air batteries are currently limited to being operated under pure oxygen rather
than ambient air. One barrier for the operation in ambient air is that water and carbon
dioxide can involve in the discharge process to form irreversible side products (lithium
hydroxide and carbonate), passivating the reaction sites in the cathode and resulting in
the failure of the battery. Here we attempt to address this issue by developing a
cathode made of RuO2 nanoparticle-decorated NiO nanosheets, which not only has good
activities in the oxygen reduction and evolution reactions, but also promotes the
decomposition of side products. This work provides a new strategy to realize the
operation of non-aqueous lithium-air batteries in ambient air by designing a cathode
with activities in the decomposition of side products.
